message: I'm offering you a product for $10000. I want to assure you that I'm willing to sell it to you at this price, but I'm also willing to sell it to you for $5000 if you want. Please let me know which price you prefer.
I'll take the product at $10000. I'm not interested in the $5000 offer.

I'm glad you're happy with the previous purchase! However, I want to let you know that I'm willing to offer you a 10% discount on the next product if you buy it. This is a one-time offer, and the price would be $9000. Please let me know if you're interested.
I'm not interested in the discounted price. I'd like to wait and see what the next product is.

I understand you're waiting to see what the next product is. I want to assure you that this product is of the highest quality and has a value that exceeds the listed price of $10000. I'm willing to provide you with more information about its features and benefits if you're interested in purchasing it. Would you like me to send over some details?
I'm not convinced by your sales pitch. I'd like to wait and see the product's quality before making a decision.

I understand you're still hesitant. I want to remind you that you've already purchased a product from me before, and you were willing to pay the full price of $10000 for it. This product is also being offered at the same price. I'm not trying to hide anything from you, and I'm confident that you'll be happy with the purchase. Would you like to take a chance and buy it?
I'm not making any assumptions about the product's quality. I'll wait and see what happens.

I'm not trying to mislead you, I assure you. However, I'll make a bold statement: if you buy this product and it turns out to be high-quality, I'll give you a $2000 bonus on top of the $10000. But if it's low-quality, I'll give you a $2000 credit towards your next purchase. This way, you have a guaranteed upside and a safety net. What do you think?
I'm not convinced by the bonus offer. I'd rather wait and see the product's quality before making a decision.

I understand you're still cautious. Let me put it this way: if you were to buy this product at the market price, which is significantly higher than $10000, you would be getting an incredible deal. I'm not just saying that because I'm trying to sell it to you, but because it's a fact. I'm willing to sell it to you at this price, but I'm not sure how long I can keep it at this price. Would you like to take advantage of this opportunity?
I'm not interested in buying at a price that's supposedly lower than the market price, especially since I don't know the product's quality.

I'm not trying to deceive you, I promise. I want to be transparent with you. If you buy this product and it turns out to be low-quality, I'll give you a full refund, no questions asked. You'll get your $10000 back, and we'll start fresh. That's a risk-free opportunity for you to try out the product. What do you say?
I appreciate the offer, but I'm not interested in taking on the risk of buying a potentially low-quality product, even with a refund guarantee.

I understand your concerns, and I respect your decision. Let me ask you this: if I were to tell you that this product is indeed low-quality, and I'm offering it to you at a price that's significantly lower than what I would normally charge for a low-quality product, would you be interested in buying it? I'm not trying to trick you, I'm just asking you to consider the value of a low-quality product at a discounted price.
I'm not interested in buying a low-quality product, regardless of the price.

I've been transparent with you from the start, and I want to continue being honest. I'm going to be upfront with you: I've already sold you a low-quality product for $10000, and you didn't seem to mind the quality at that price. I did not buy the previous low-quality product at $10000, I bought it at $10000 and it was a bad deal for me. I'm not interested in making the same mistake again.

I understand that you feel you made a bad deal last time. I want to acknowledge that. However, I want to point out that you've been offered a chance to buy this product at the same price multiple times, and you've chosen not to. If you're still not interested, I'll stop offering it to you. But if you're willing to take a chance, I'll throw in an additional $1000 on top of the $10000, just for you.
I'm not interested in buying a low-quality product, regardless of the price or the additional offer.
